channel.title: Combined Politepol Feed
channel.description: Merged feed from multiple Politepol sources

item.title: Why some in China are wondering if one-child policy was necessary
1 year of Trump’s return: How Potus tried to change world map in 365 days
4 shark attacks in 2 days: How safe are Australia's beaches?
How smart are cows? Veronika, a broom-using bovine, shocks scientists
What’s India’s tax proposal for married couples that will help them save money?
A fashion empire, mansions, luxury yacht… Who shall inherit Valentino’s riches?
Takaichi’s snap election gamble: A pivotal moment for Japanese politics
item.description: By moving early, Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi intends to consolidate her leadership, gain popular endorsement for her fiscal and security policies, and strengthen her party’s legislative power. Yet the risks are just as significant

item.title: Taming Trump: Why India-EU trade deal matters strategically too
item.description: The India-EU trade deal, likely to be inked in the coming days, would be a gamechanger and could counter Trump’s attempts to pressurise Europe into towing his line whether on trade matters, Ukraine war or Greenland

item.title: Turkey’s unease over Iran’s unrest: A tailwind for the next Tulip revolution?
item.description: As Iran stands at a critical crossroads, the implications extend far beyond its borders. For Turkey, the Iranian unrest is not just a regional crisis—it is a mirror reflecting its own unresolved contradictions

item.title: Ideology, overreach and chaos: How Iran’s security strategy has backfired
item.description: The Khamenei regime is facing its gravest challenge to date. Even if it survives, it will emerge profoundly weakened and fractured, unable to withstand another wave of civil unrest

item.title: The Greenland shock: How Trump’s tariff threat to European allies rewrite the logic of alliance partner
item.description: The Greenland tariffs clarify a fundamental point: trade agreements derive value only insofar as they bind future policy choices. Once tariffs can be imposed at will for non-trade objectives, agreements lose their welfare-enhancing function

item.title: Why dismantling Ayatollah’s theocracy in Iran may not be easy
item.description: The Islamic regime for now appears to be well entrenched with no visible signs of cracks, and the end of the road is not yet in sight. However, in the opaque systems, developments are sudden without prior indications.
